sentences.sentence: YOUR VIEW: Letters to the editor: our readers share their views.

Please send your letters toletters@independent.co.ukWho on earth is surprised that thefar-right thugswho claimed they were in Whitehall on Armistice Day to defend statues (that did not need protecting) ended up fighting with the police?The rhetoric aroundcountering another march, labelled bySuella Bravermanas a hate march, is not only mendacious and insulting, but factually incorrect.
The peace attendees started over two miles away on Park Lane and never went near the Cenotaph.

Thehome secretaryand all those supporting her should be ashamed of themselves for actively rabble-rousing the dregs of our country!Robert BostonKentBraverman is a scapegoat - violence at the protests was inevitableDoes anyone really believe that if Suella Braverman hadkept her thoughts to herselfand not publicly taunted the police with her “right-wing bias” drivel, the hideous rent-a-mob would not have turned up in London to counter the ceasefire march?It was an inevitable byproduct of the peace march, and while their right to peacefully protest was successfully supported by the police, there is no doubt that many (including me) thought their timing was inappropriate and insensitive.Braverman's a nice easy target to blame, but getting rid of her won't change the attitudes of the 90-odd far-right thugs arrested for disorder in the City or the attitudes of people who provocatively carry bloodied dolls in shrouds to anti-war marches on Armistice Day.Steve MackinderDenverFarage got off easyIn light of the comments made in WhatsApp and email messages by senior staff in Boris Johnson's government, revealed in evidence to the Covid inquiry, I think Nigel Farage got off lightly in being called a “crackpot”, “sketchy” and “a fool” by staff at NatWest Bank.I suggest he stops his crusade against the bank before he finds out what peoplereally think of him.Helen BoreScarboroughAI music can't compete with the real thingAs a lifelong Kate Bush fan, I was gutted that her world record for time between number-one singles has beenpipped by The Beatleswith an engineered, rather poor facsimile of a record.It feels genuinely disappointing that an artificial attempt has so easily made it to number one.
Whereas hers was a genuine phenomenon, this feels like a crass marketing ploy.Laura DawsonHarpenden

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: YOUR VIEW: Letters to the editor: our readers share their views. Please send your letters toletters@independent.co.ukWho on earth is surprised that thefar-right thugswho claimed they were in Whitehall on Armistice Day to defend statues (that did not need protecting) ended up fighting with the police?The rhetoric aroundcountering another march, labelled bySuella Bravermanas a hate march, is not only mendacious and insulting, but factually incorrect. The peace attendees started over two miles away on Park Lane and never went near the Cenotaph. Thehome secretaryand all those supporting her should be ashamed of themselves for actively rabble-rousing the dregs of our country!Robert BostonKentBraverman is a scapegoat – violence at the protests was inevitableDoes anyone really believe that if Suella Braverman hadkept her thoughts to herselfand not publicly taunted the police with her “right-wing bias” drivel, the hideous rent-a-mob would not have turned up in London to counter the ceasefire march?It was an inevitable byproduct of the peace march, and while their right to peacefully protest was successfully supported by the police, there is no doubt that many (including me) thought their timing was inappropriate and insensitive.Braverman’s a nice easy target to blame, but getting rid of her won’t change the attitudes of the 90-odd far-right thugs arrested for disorder in the City or the attitudes of people who provocatively carry bloodied dolls in shrouds to anti-war marches on Armistice Day.Steve MackinderDenverFarage got off easyIn light of the comments made in WhatsApp and email messages by senior staff in Boris Johnson’s government, revealed in evidence to the Covid inquiry, I think Nigel Farage got off lightly in being called a “crackpot”, “sketchy” and “a fool” by staff at NatWest Bank.I suggest he stops his crusade against the bank before he finds out what peoplereally think of him.Helen BoreScarboroughAI music can’t compete with the real thingAs a lifelong Kate Bush fan, I was gutted that her world record for time between number-one singles has beenpipped by The Beatleswith an engineered, rather poor facsimile of a record.It feels genuinely disappointing that an artificial attempt has so easily made it to number one. Whereas hers was a genuine phenomenon, this feels like a crass marketing ploy.Laura DawsonHarpenden
